semantic_title: MRSA Colonization and Infection - Coding Both Conditions During Same Admission
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 1. Certain Infectious and Parasitic Diseases > e. Methicillin Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) Conditions > 1) Selection and sequencing of MRSA codes > (d) MRSA colonization and infection

content.full_text: If a patient is documented as having both MRSA colonization and infection during a hospital admission, code Z22.322, Carrier or suspected carrier of Methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus, and a code for the MRSA infection may both be assigned. (Evidence: pg no: 28, L27-L29)
content.summary: Guidelines for coding when a patient has both MRSA colonization and active MRSA infection during the same hospital stay (Evidence: pg no: 28, L27-L29)
key_concepts: Dual coding for MRSA colonization and infection (Evidence: pg no: 28, L27-L29)
Hospital admission context (Evidence: pg no: 28, L28)
Carrier status with active infection (Evidence: pg no: 28, L29)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Both MRSA colonization and infection codes may be assigned when documented during same admission (Evidence: pg no: 28, L27-L29)
detailed_rules.explanation: When a patient has documented MRSA colonization and also develops or has an active MRSA infection during the same hospital admission, both conditions should be coded separately (Evidence: pg no: 28, L27-L29)
common_applications: Patient admitted with MRSA colonization who develops MRSA infection
Patient with known MRSA carrier status presenting with MRSA infection

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify documentation of MRSA colonization during admission
Step 2: Identify documentation of MRSA infection during same admission
Step 4: Assign appropriate MRSA infection code

specific_codes.description: Carrier or suspected carrier of Methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (Evidence: pg no: 28, L29)
specific_codes.context: Used for MRSA colonization when patient also has active infection

references_to.title: MRSA and MSSA colonization

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient admitted with known MRSA colonization develops pneumonia due to MRSA during admission
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient with MRSA colonization, developed MRSA pneumonia during hospitalization

correct_coding.sequencing: MRSA infection as primary, colonization as additional
correct_coding.rationale: Both conditions are documented and should be coded separately (Evidence: pg no: 28, L27-L29)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Missing the colonization code when both conditions are documented
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Failing to code colonization when infection is also present

warnings: Both codes may be assigned only when both conditions are documented during the same admission (Evidence: pg no: 28, L27-L29)
best_practices: Review documentation carefully to identify both colonization and infection status
Code both conditions when clearly documented
common_mistakes: Coding only the infection and missing the colonization status
Assuming colonization when only infection is documented
tips: Look for documentation of both carrier status and active infection
Hospital admission context is important for this guideline
clinical_context: Common in hospital settings where patients are screened for MRSA
Important for infection control and treatment planning
